sentence.text: Although anti-myelin-associated glycoprotein (transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair) antibody neuropathy is reported as a slowly progressive disease, it can lead to significant disability and impairment of health-related quality of life (HR-QoL) and social participation.

The aim of this cross-sectional study was to evaluate the functioning and HR-QoL determinants in 67 patients with anti-transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair neuropathy in terms of the International Classification of Functioning, Disability, and Health (ICF).

Furthermore, neurorehabilitation interventions aimed at improving balance and walking performance, fatigue management, and specific pain relief therapy should be considered to ameliorate participation in social life and regulation of transcription, DNA-templated-QoL in anti-transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair neuropathy patients
